Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Coordination and Cooperation in Networked Multi-Agent Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Networked wireless systems have significantly affected society, as cellular and WiFi networks are now ubiquitous in our daily life. An important class of networks is that of decentralized networks, which are characterized by a lack of fixed infrastructure, a multi-hop nature, and node mobility; such features provide significant flexibility, but also introduce a variety of design issues. A fundamental problem in decentralized networked systems is the coordination of activities of different nodes, where the availability of sufficient communication resources is critical in order for agents to cooperate and coordinate. This project takes a distinctive approach to develop a fundamental understanding of the interplay between communication and cooperation to achieve coordination and addresses the communication and coordination of probabilistic actions in networked multi-agent systems. This can be seen as an instance of network-based stochastic open loop control where a single communication message is sent to the agents to control their behavior in the absence of feedback. The project investigates two interrelated research tasks. First, the PIs wish to understand both the fundamental information-theoretic limits of coordination in small multi-terminal networks and the dependency of these limits on the communication network topology. The second research goal addresses the design of explicit coordination codes from error correction codes and to assess their performance under stringent delay and complexity constraints.

The proposed research has the potential to enable advances in applications where actions must be communicated to ensure a specific behavior. Examples are multi-agent systems for the exploration of an unknown topology, distributed surveillance applications, automatic traffic control applications, and load balancing in large computer networks and in power grids. Additional activities related to the project include the integration of research outcomes in courses at the undergraduate and graduate level and the mentorship of minorities and women in science and technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study has focused on communicating and coordinating actions in networked multi-agent systems -- in particular on building systematic tools to study fundamental performance limits of these systems and on the analysis and design of practical coding schemes for coordination.

In recent years, networked wireless systems have emerged in many applications and have significantly affected society as cellular or WiFi networks are now ubiquitous in our daily life. An important class is that of decentralized networks such as ad hoc networks. Common among these types of networks is the lack of any fixed infrastructure, a multihop nature, and often node mobility; these features generate significant flexibility, but also a variety of new design issues compared to structured networks. One fundamental problem in decentralized networked systems is to coordinate activities of different nodes such that they reach a state of agreement or “consensus” on a specific quantity of interest. While this problem has been addressed extensively in the literature, this project has studied a generalization where consensus is meant in a broader sense of imposing coordinated actions by cooperation between the network nodes or agents, and therefore can be seen as an instance of distributed control.

In particular, two important issues were addressed. First, the project has provided insights for the practically important case of coordination over networks. Specifically, we have studied the line network setting, in which agent A is connected to agent B, and B to agent B to agent C and so on, and all agents are required to jointly coordinate their actions to achieve a desired target behavior specified by the system designer. This target behavior is modelled by the joint probability distribution between the actions of all agents. For this setting, we have derived an inner bound to the smallest possible communication rate, which is equivalent to the smallest amount of exchanged information to obtain the desired target behavior. This bound is tight for some special cases. We then extended these results to noisy and error prone communication channels between two agents. For the simple case of so called discrete memoryless channels we have studied scenarios where joint coding for coordination and error correction can provide some benefits compared to a separate design of coordination and channel codes. This result is quite surprising as by naively interpreting coordination encoding as a source compression operation joint coding should not have any advantage over separate coding according to Shannon's separation principle.

Second, we have proposed a practical scheme for coordination of two agents A and B over noisy communication channels. This scheme is based on polar codes and provides a constructive alternative to the previously used random coding solution, which cannot be implemented in polynomial time. In contrast, our encoding and decoding scheme has a complexity which is quasilinear in time and is therefore in principle implementable on current hardware.

Further, this project helped to provide training and professional development to a Ph.D. student at the New Jersey Institute of Technology. By integrating some of these research problems and their solutions into the curriculum of the PI’s coding graduate class (specifically with respect to polar codes), the project also enabled exposing students to state-of-the-art research questions. The results of this project have been disseminated via publications in journals and presentation at international conferences within the information theory and coding community.
